WRITING.TITLE: Trade wars, Brexit are 'profit warning', Dutch king says

WRITING.TEXT: gt;Once again. Why is this country in the EU? No one really knows. Apparently, nowadays it's more important to keep countries in the EU at all cost trying not to offend them too much than it is to actually defend what the EU is supposed to be about. The irony of it all is, that the longer the EU allows this kinda behaviour (attacking [journalists](https://www.politico.eu/article/polands-pis-law-and-justice-party-aims-to-regulate-journalists-media-after-the-election/), [judges](https://euobserver.com/justice/145685), [gays](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/poland-lgbt-free-zones-homophobia-hate-speech-law-justice-party-a9013551.html)) to continue, the bigger the chance the EU will split into a two-speed union, which is what Poland (and other EE countries) do not want. gt;There isn't supposed to be a committee to value respect to human rights before letting anyone in? Yes, every country has to meet the [Copenhagen criteria](https://ec.europa.eu/neighbourhood-enlargement/policy/glossary/terms/accession-criteria_en) if it wants to join our Union. The sad thing is, the moment a country actually joins, no one gives a shit about those criteria anymore and they can do whatever they want. Those criteria are just a bar to *enter* our Union. Once they're in, they don't matter anymore.
He's got a book coming out.
gt;Boris was compelled to cancel the presser after anti-Brexit protesters **heckled** him. Hulk can't handle a bit of yelling? Tsk.
Cause it is. This is as anti-gay as it gets. You're ignorant if you think it isn't. And there should be no place for it in the EU.

gt; I agree that generalization is not great/helpful At what point does something stop being a generalization, though? PiS has [46%](https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/poland/) support in the polls. Over half of 'm believe gays are the *single biggest threat* to the country, and I bet the other half sees 'm as the second or third biggest threat. I think it's safe to say that almost half the country sees gays as a threat. Hardly a generalization anymore. No, Poland has a problem in the gay department and calling it a generalization is only adding to that problem.
Morons.
Me neither. I usually don't believe people who start with "I voted remain, but".

Well, Guardian is fake news, according to Brexiteers, so it's probably not true then. Either that or Boris "The Hulk" Johnson gets intimidated by a tiny country's PM, which would be rather embarrassing for a superpower like the UK. I also like to take the opportunity to recall that Boris called us a bunch of [Nazis](https://www.politico.eu/article/boris-johnson-compares-eu-to-nazi-superstate-brexit-ukip/) and didn't take it back. Maybe there's the problem.
Imagine having to rely on Trump's ambassador. This is getting kinda embarrassing, UK.

Of course, he should. A PM with balls would face the crowd. Especially someone who identifies himself with the Hulk. But this is all set up to play the victim, which is an essential part of the populist playbook. Now they can blame the EU and that was always the point of having Boris as a PM. Brexiteers want to crash out of the EU one way or another and blame the EU for it. Everything that happens now with Boris as PM must be seen in that regard.

I guess it's kinda hard to get a tertiary degree in countries where they [kick out](https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2018/12/04/central-european-university-forced-out-hungary-moving-vienna) universities and [shit](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hungary-scientists-protests/hungarians-protest-over-government-overhaul-of-academic-bodies-idUSKCN1T30KE) on academics. Yes, this happens in the EU.

Oooh, the methods are different. It's all good then... You don't go there. You just don't. Did I mention already that he [refused](https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-eu-referendum-36295208) to take it back?
Welcome to the EU.

gt; How the fuck did we get here? Besides wanting to arrest MPs and judges, they also want to regulate [journalists](https://www.politico.eu/article/polands-pis-law-and-justice-party-aims-to-regulate-journalists-media-after-the-election/) and hate [gays](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/poland-lgbt-free-zones-homophobia-hate-speech-law-justice-party-a9013551.html) and shit on other minorities. And that's just the beginning. It should be noted that PiS has almost [half](https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/poland/) of the votes, so it's not a minor or temporary problem. Half of the country agrees with this. This attitude is structural and deeply embedded in Polish society. The more pertinent question to me is not how the fuck they got there, but how the fuck do we get rid of it? There should be no place for countries like this in the EU. And I'll keep on saying it till things change for the good.

She's EPP, so it was to be expected. I'm disgusted by the attitude that the EU must be held together at all cost, even if it means going against everything it's supposed to stand for and allowing de facto autocratic regimes to rise up. It makes me sick that I'm part of such a Union. And it's only getting worse and worse by the day.

gt;We were like that all the time. Even worse then. I'm not talking about imprisoning people, I'm merely stating that there should be no place for countries like this in the EU. It literally goes against our Treaty and against everything the EU stands for. I'm saying *this* Poland does not belong in our Union. Outside of it, they can do whatever they want. I couldn't care less.

Please, don't downplay the problem. 50% of the votes is 50%. People that don't bother to vote, apparently don't care much about what's going on. Not enough to go out and vote against this bullshit anyway. Which, in a way, is agreeing with it.

gt;So therewas no "other" Poland - only passing stage Yes, and that's when they joined the EU. During that passing stage. Which, as it seems, was all a sham. A farce. You deceived and betrayed the rest of us. gt;but the aim was getting rich Yes, and that was the (only, or at least main) reason for them to join the EU. gt;There is no "other" Poland. Yes, and that's exactly why there is no place for it in the EU. So we have a problem. I, for one, do not want to be part of a union with countries like this in it. And I can assure you, [I'm not the only one](https://eu2019.fi/en/backgrounders/rule-of-law). Far from it. Either Poland changes and starts playing by EU's rules (which, according to you, it will never do), or it should be forced out of our union. Cause what's happening now, can't go on. Sooner or later it will lead to a clash. And I hope it will be sooner rather than later. You can be autocratic and nationalistic outside the EU all you want.

gt;I give it like 14 Years I sure hope it will be sooner. Again, the sooner, the better. gt;after that time money from EU will be either marginal or Poland will be net payer And then people get mad when they call Poland a leech... I've always said that Poland will stop loving the EU the moment they will have to start coughing up dough. Your "support" for the EU, isn't really about the EU and I hope the rest of the EU will finally start realizing this. The moment you will have to pay, is the very moment support for the EU will drop drastically. gt;If we leave it will probably be Italy and afterwards Spain... Fine with me. I wouldn't care if the EU collapsed. Even though I'm pro-EU, it's not sacred to me. We can start over with a new and improved Union. Without autocratic countries. As a matter of fact, Poland could serve as a perfect buffer between the democratic West and autocratic Russia. Edit: Please take Hungary with you when you leave.
gt; the agreement will be issued by the Highest Court Which they aim to control.

gt; we pay so we demand Except that it doesn't really work like that in the EU. You wouldn't know, cause you never paid. My country is the biggest net contributor per capita and yours is the biggest net receiver (total). Yet, you do whatever you want anyway. That's my whole point. But it will never get that far. I think we can both agree that Poland will never be a net contributor. It will leave before that happens. Cause - as you yourself stated correctly - it has always been about the money. The moment you will have to actually *give* money, is the moment the EU will lose its purpose to your country. And then you'll leave. Hopefully. We're a cash cow. And that's it. There is no need for Poland to stay in the EU, once it has to start paying. I'm really glad your economy is booming.

gt; If they wanted to arrest opposition MPs, they can do it now. Except that this would be something the EU really couldn't possibly ignore if it wants to keep any of its credibility. The EU is already ignoring a lot of what's going on in Poland, but actually arresting opposition would be a step too far. At least, I hope (cause I'm not really sure anymore these days). So what do you do then? You make it *look* like it's ok by using the Highest Court instead. All you need to do is control that court and the EU will be fine with it. gt;at least 66% votes They're at 46% now. Once they have an actual majority (50% +1), they can start changing things that will make any opposition impossible, which will lead to 2/3 of the votes sooner or later. It's straight out of the populist/autocratic playbook. Honestly, you're really blind if you don't see this happening. It's not really a debate anymore. We can all see it.
11 days... Oh my. I'd squeeze Rome in there somehow. Enjoy your trip.

gt;The EU is in reality an economic alliance that saves this continent from US and China domination. Then why do we have a Treaty with democratic values? I'm ok with an economic alliance, but we don't need an EU for that. But as long as we have an EU, I will keep bitching about it, cause those "lofty" values are important to me. If it's all about the economy, we should get rid of the EU, which will lead to a two-speed Europe (a democratic part and an autocratic part), which is what countries like Poland [don't want](https://www.euractiv.com/section/future-eu/news/polands-kaczynski-warns-two-speed-europe-leads-to-breakdown/) either.

That's how a lot of autocrats start. They present themselves as progressive reformers with respect for the rule of law and democratic values. That's how they get elected and build a base. It goes well for a while, but over time, they change. Hungary is another prime example of it. Orb #225;n used to be a democrat. Venezuela is another example. Not all autocrats are like that, though. At least Duterte was honest about it from the get-go.
Imagine living in a world where that's the biggest problem... But I'm sure Piers won't get that since he lost touch with reality ages ago already.

gt;In the EU, some countries are more equal than others. gt; Just saying that the standard for when that is deemed so offending as to warrant a rejection isn #8217;t the same for candidates from all countries. I might hope so. It would be rather foolish if there weren't different standards because countries *within* the EU use different standards *themselves*. Some countries are sliding into authoritarian regimes as we speak, most prominently reflected in a complete lack of respect for the rule of law. So, some countries in the EU are (way) more democratic than others. It would be rather weird to treat them the same. If they don't like that, they should work on it. If he or she is corrupt or otherwise compromised, he/she should be booted. All I'm saying is there's a different level of credibility countries have due to the different standards and systems they uphold. And that affects the whole political spectrum of a country, from the mayor of the tiniest village up to the Commissioner in the EU. WRITING.TEXT: What is bullshit exactly? [Climate change](https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/)?

Then it still should be against the current Israeli government, and not against Jews. I myself am very critical of the Netanyahu-government as well, but I don't have a beef with Jews. Two different things and the fact that you can't make that distinction yourself, is telling. It's even more troubling that your president can't tell the difference. But hey, he's PiS, so I wouldn't expect anything else. We all know they're not the smartest people in the room.

Yes, they [have](https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/jul/02/norway-electric-cars-subsidies-fossil-fuel). gt;Buyers escape heavy import or purchase taxes and are also exempt from 25% VAT. They also avoid road tax, road tolls, pay half price on ferries, get free municipal parking in cities and can usually use bus lanes. The same happened over here, by the way, but on a (much) smaller scale.
/r/woooosh
Believe so, too. And that's a good thing, cause those subsidies were a [disgrace](https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2019/01/electric-car-subsidies-largely-benefit-rich-tesla-and-jaguar-drivers/).
gt; Only about half of current warming is likely to be human caused as per current research and that is even wild guesses at best. What research would that be? Honest question. Would like to read it.

First of all, most climate scientists believe that human activities are the [main cause](https://www.science.org.au/learning/general-audience/science-climate-change/3-are-human-activities-causing-climate-change), by far. gt;Most of the observed recent global warming results from human activities Climatic warming or cooling arises from changes in the flows of energy through the climate system (Figure 1.1) that can originate from a number of possible driving factors. The main drivers that have acted over the last century are: gt; - increases in atmospheric CO2 and other long-lived greenhouse gases (methane, nitrous oxide and halocarbons) gt; - increases in short-lived greenhouse gases (mainly ozone) changes to land cover (replacement of darker forests with paler croplands and grasslands) gt; - increases in aerosols (tiny particles in the atmosphere) gt; - solar fluctuations (changes in the brightness of the sun) volcanic eruptions. gt; Of these, solar fluctuations and volcanic eruptions are entirely natural, **while the other four are predominantly caused by human influences. The human-induced drivers have been dominant over the past century** (Figure 3.4). Changes in greenhouse gas concentrations, dominated by CO2, caused a large warming contribution. Some of this has been offset by the net cooling effects of increased aerosol concentrations and their impact on clouds. Black carbon or soot has probably exerted a smaller, warming influence. The net effect of all aerosol types including soot remains hard to quantify accurately. Among the natural influences, the effect of changes in the brightness of the Sun has been very small (Box 3.1). Volcanic influences are highly intermittent, with major eruptions (such as Pinatubo in 1991) causing significant cooling for a year or two, but their average effects over the past century have been relatively small. Second of all, even it was half, that's still a [lot](https://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/climate/faq/how-do-human-activities-contribute-to-climate-change-and-how-do-they-compare-with-natural-influences).

/r/ENLIGHTENEDCENTRISM

I'm not saying you're entirely wrong, but I'm using the word in the way most of us (including media, politicians and the common man) use it in our daily language. Your definition of 'populism' is not the same as our current usage of it. Again, not saying you're wrong, but we use the word in a different manner nowadays. It kinda reminds me of what our PM said after last elections: #8220;After Brexit and the American election, the Netherlands has said no to *the wrong kind of populism*, #8221; Rutte told the crowds at his victory [speech](https://www.politico.eu/article/mark-ruttes-right-kind-of-populism/).

What makes you think the long-term effects of Brexit will be positive for the UK? That's highly uncertain. No one really knows, tbh. Most economists believe [it won't be positive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_effects_of_Brexit#Long-term_impact_on_the_UK_economy). So claiming things will be better in the long run is based on pretty much nothing but your gut-feeling. And, of course, the EU will suffer as well. Everyone suffers from Brexit, especially with a no-deal. But more than the UK? That's highly debatable as well. And it's not so much about suffering at this point anymore. There's just little confidence in the rest of the EU anymore that the UK will reach consensus on how to leave. And your first argument about the poor families, you can use that argument on pretty much any government spending (military, farmers, health care). If you're gonna make that argument, you need to look at the bigger picture and total spendings (look at [this](https://www.reddit.com/r/europe/comments/ddk24h/britain_paid_150m_a_week_to_europe_not_350m_as/f2ivnnd/) comment); the contribution to the EU is nothing compared to other spendings. Even more so when you consider it's not money thrown away since the UK gets a lot back for it as well.

No. Number [90](https://rsf.org/en/serbia) on the Press Freedom Index (14 points *down* compared to 2018, so instead of improving, it's getting *worse*). Number [78](http://data.worldjusticeproject.org/) on the Rule of Law Index (*down* from number 76 in 2018, so instead of improving, it's getting *worse*). Number [87](https://www.transparency.org/cpi2018) on the Corruption Perception Index (*down* from number 77 in 2017, so instead of improving, it's getting *worse*). Serbia is not even close to meeting EU's criteria. And instead of working towards meeting those criteria, they're moving away from 'm. We already have to deal with Hungary in the EU, breaking those criteria. Sorry, but that's more than enough already.

Why should *we* be the *only* ones "opening up"? Why does it *always* have to be us? What does that even mean? Does it mean I have to accept authoritarian and anti-gay behavior? It goes both ways these days. A growing number of Eastern Europeans regard countries in the Western part of Europe as failed societies due to immigration and multi-culturalism. I don't feel any obligation to "open up". And I definitely don't see the West as the "bad guy" who has the sole responsibility to overcome the clear division between East and West. I'm sick and tired of being blamed for that.
